greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers m such that the sum of the first k divisors and the last k divisors of m is equal to 2*m for some k that is smaller than half of the number of divisors of m.
comment: If k is allowed to be equal to half of the number of divisors of m, then the perfect numbers (A000396) will be terms.
example: 36 is a term since its divisors are {1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36} and the sum of the first 3 and last 3 divisors is (1 + 2 + 3) + (12 + 18 + 36) = 72 = 2 * 36.
mathematica: seqQ[n_] := Module[{d = Divisors[n]}, nd = Length[d]; nd2 = Ceiling[nd/2] - 1; s = Accumulate[d[[1 ;; nd2]] + n/d[[1 ;; nd2]]]; MemberQ[s, 2*n]]; Select[Range[10^6], seqQ]
xref: A variant of A194472 and A318168.
results.author: _Amiram Eldar_, Apr 27 2020
